title: Dead to Sin, Alive in Christ
shortSummary: Romans chapter 6 teaches believers about the transformative power of baptism and union with Christ in His death and resurrection. It emphasizes that Christians are no longer slaves to sin but are called to live righteously under grace, not the law. This chapter highlights the believer’s new identity and the call to holiness through the power of Christ.
timeline: c. AD 57 - Paul's Epistle to the Romans, written during his third missionary journey

keyCharacters.name: Paul
keyCharacters.description: The apostle who authored Romans, explaining theological truths about sin, grace, and new life in Christ.

keyCharacters.name: Jesus Christ
keyCharacters.description: Central figure whose death and resurrection provide the basis for believers’ freedom from sin and newness of life.

definitions.definition: A Christian ordinance symbolizing the believer’s identification with Christ’s death, burial, and resurrection.
A term referring to the believer’s former sinful nature that is crucified with Christ.
God’s unmerited favor that empowers believers to live righteously apart from the law.
Authority or control; here it refers to sin’s power over a person.

outline.heading: The Question of Continuing in Sin
outline.description: Paul addresses a potential misunderstanding that grace might encourage sinning, firmly rejecting this idea by affirming that believers are dead to sin.

outline.heading: Union with Christ in Baptism
outline.description: Paul explains that baptism symbolizes believers’ participation in Christ’s death and resurrection, resulting in a new life.

outline.heading: Crucifixion of the Old Self
outline.description: The believer’s old sinful nature is crucified with Christ so that sin’s power is broken, enabling a life alive to God.

outline.heading: Exhortation to Live Righteously
outline.description: Believers are urged not to let sin reign in their bodies but to live under grace, which empowers them to overcome sin.

outline.heading: Slaves to Righteousness
outline.description: Paul contrasts slavery to sin resulting in death with slavery to righteousness resulting in holiness and eternal life, urging believers to yield themselves to God.

application: Recognize your identity in Christ as dead to sin and alive to God, allowing this truth to shape your daily choices.
Do not use grace as a license to sin; instead, yield your body as an instrument of righteousness through obedience to God.
Remember that sin’s power is broken in your life, so resist temptation and pursue holiness actively.
Serve God wholeheartedly, understanding that obedience leads to eternal life and spiritual fruitfulness.

keyVerses.text: Therefore we are buried with him by baptism into death: that like as Christ was raised up from the dead by the glory of the Father, even so we also should walk in newness of life.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the believer’s new life in Christ, symbolized through baptism, emphasizing transformation and resurrection power.

keyVerses.text: Likewise reckon ye also yourselves to be dead indeed unto sin, but alive unto God through Jesus Christ our Lord.
keyVerses.significance: It calls believers to a mindset of identifying with Christ’s death to sin and living fully for God.

keyVerses.text: For sin shall not have dominion over you: for ye are not under the law, but under grace.
keyVerses.significance: This verse assures believers of victory over sin through grace rather than the law’s condemnation.

keyVerses.text: For the wages of sin is death; but the gift of God is eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord.
keyVerses.significance: It contrasts the consequences of sin with the free gift of eternal life, summarizing the gospel’s core message.
